top_comment.text:
So, for those of you that played Revengance (stay with me on this one, I 
have a valid point), you'd know that the main rival of Raiden is a cyborg 
named Sam. All throughout the game, he had Raiden on the back foot, and 
everyone assumed that he had a better cyborg body. But then Raiden finally 
kills Sam, and it turns out he wasn't even a cyborg, he just pretended to 
be. All that time everyone thought his skill came from his cyborg implants, 
but he was just an godlike fighter. That's what I like to think happened 
with Tarkus. He went to this land human, with all of his knights, 
pretending to be undead so that he could get a challenge worthy of him. 
When he finally perished, he died as a man, not a hollow. Of course this 
has holes in it, it's just what I like to think.﻿

if you actually look into why the story is like this, the director of the 
series actually builds the story on how he read medieval books as a kid. 
they were almost always in english and, he didn't fully know the language. 
so he would constantly be making up parts for himself as he went along. his 
own personal story if you will. he wanted to give players the same feeling, 
that each battle is its own duel with a currently skilled opponent, that 
the story is designed and interpreted how we want to, or to figure out the 
truth ourselves.

thats how the stories designed, and outright telling us it would be 
blasphemous to the core ideal of the game

top_comment.text:
I actually don't believe Tarkus fell to his death in Anor Londo. I believe 
it's quite possible he actually made it passed the scaffolding. There were 
plenty of high, narrow paths in Sen's Fortress that he apparently bested 
(these were accompanied by enemies as well, mind you.) It's even very 
possible he entered the painted world. I think, perhaps, he and at least 
one of his fellow heavy knights of Berenike made it passed Sen's and the 
Iron Golem, and all the way into the painted world. I can imagine Tarkus 
and his heavy companion fought their way through the painting guardians, 
and through Ariamis. Upon their arrival at Priscilla's fog gate, Tarkus 
possibly ordered the heavy knight to guard the entrance, not knowing what 
may happen. Tarkus, possibly out of nobility, decided not to cause harm to 
Priscilla, and without the ability to pass back though the fog gate, did as 
Priscilla asks. He left the painted world. His death was most likely at the 
hands of the waiting guardians, perhaps they were too numerous for him to 
take alone. In the end it's all speculation. It was the only explanation I 
could find as to why there was a heavy knight in Ariamis. I feel it's not 
too far fetched.﻿

comments.text:
The world of Dark Souls is a world filled with singularities and time 
paradoxes. When you rest at a bonfire, you essentially turn time backwards 
to when the enemies were still there. When you kill NPCs, they respawn, but 
in another dimension. To them, YOU stopped respawning. The dead Tarkus we 
find is probably not the Tarkus that helps us out, but another version of 
him from another dimension.

+ThePortableTornado I relinquished my hipsterness and watched Vaati's 
videos, and he came to most of the same conclusions I did. He also opened 
my eyes to more, which cemented my understanding of both dark souls 1 and 
2. 

Both games were game changers for me; they've made me enjoy video games 
much more and brought nearly the perfect blend of what I wanted. I enjoyed 
both, and each has something about it that draws me to the game, but Dark 
Souls 2 is my favorite. 

Dark Souls 2 hits home with a few of its themes, and I feel at home in its 
world. The lore also keeps me wanting more information, and the dlc just 
sparked that interest even more. 

I like that Dark Souls 2 places more of an emphasis on the curse and what 
it means to be human. I just wish there was a combined version fitted for 
the PS4 lol.
comments.author: Jeuscifer B

comments.text:
+Jeuscifer B  +Omid Mansour 

Its refreshing to see people defending Dark Souls 2 instead of bashing it 
for not being a carbon copy of Dark Souls 1. I honestly feel that they are 
equals in terms of quality, and that one game is stronger in areas the 
other was a bit weak in.

I love the stories for both games, they are both genuinely fantastic. I 
just wish DS2 had a few more stories to the NPC's. Granted they still have 
some interesting bits to them, and the fact that nearly ALL of them are 
slowly losing their memories... its unnerving to say the least and really 
goes to reinforce the desperation to figure out the curse.

(also check out Vaati's videos on DS2's lore, they're quite good and 
confirmed several of my suspicions while presenting some ideas I hadn't 
considered)

comments.text:
There are plenty of corpses in Dark Souls--from the corpse flung through 
the bars separating you from the Stray Demon in the Undead Asylum to the 
numerous "lost souls" spread throughout the world.  

I think the process of hollowing is not only gradual, but also 
constricting:  you start off with just a cursed brand and your life.  You 
die, then you come back, except not all the way.  You are living, but your 
body is corroding and you have to "reinforce" yourself, your weapons, 
everything around you with souls gained from others.  

Everything around you will corrode if you don't reinforce it.  Every death 
you undergo lessens your ability to reinforce, and further strips what you 
have.  It's a case of literally *becoming hollow*, of having all your 
substance torn away.  The shambling hollows you encounter early on have no 
more clothes or hair, their swords are broken nubs, and they have no mind 
to do anything except for sensing your reinforced souls and attacking you.  

Finally, when hollows truly give up, you see them huddled in corners or 
crying and praying (such as in New Londo).  Eventually they stop moving, 
and their bodies just rot.  As a result, the only thing left of them is 
their "lost" soul, which never dies, but becomes part of the bonfire 
reinforcement that you use to keep yourself from hollowing.

I think it's interesting to see where these rotting bodies end up, because 
they each tell a story.  Even the one who gives you your pyro flame or 
catalyst at the beginning is a little tale of some undead soul who had only 
one goal, and when that failed, they just sat down to die, clutching the 
one last thing that mattered to them.  It's sad, but not in a bad way. :)
comments.author: milesbennettdyson

comments.text:
Even for the Undead, a true death is possible. Each death brings the 
process of Hollowing further and further to completion, Those who 
completely lose their humanity become mindless Hollows, but even then these 
mindless beasts still cling to some small hope: Souls. The desire to gain 
souls in the hope of becoming whole again becomes all-consuming to Hollows 
and is their entire reason for existing. But once all hope has finally 
faded, an Undead goes still, never to move again. It is possible, and quite 
likely, that Tarkus died many times trying to conquer Sen's Fortress, but 
his indomitable strength and will let him keep going. Once he finally 
reached Anor Londo, however, he encountered a situation that his skill left 
him completely inept to face. This realization that this obstacle was all 
but insurmountable to a man of his training broke Tarkus so utterly that he 
'died', foregoing the Hollow stage and becoming the corpse in the corner.

captions.text: We all remember the help Tarkus gave us that day...
Tarkus was like us : someone trying to make it through the world
to uncover the truth.
The least we can do is follow in his footsteps and succeed where he failed.
The knights of Berenike are known for their heavy armor and weaponry.
There is no nation that is physically stronger.
But even among them,
There was Tarkus.
A knight renowned for having strength great enough to sport
a set of heavy black iron
that was unique to him alone.
Berenike was a land outside of Lordran
but it was not free from the curse of the undead.
As the curse spread and society crumbled countless knights became undead.
But the knights had not lost their sanity yet.
Throughout the neighboring lands, a prophecy was spreading.
An old saying from Astora that said this :
"Thou who art Undead, art chosen...
In thine exodus from the Undead Asylum, maketh pilgrimage to the land of Ancient Lords...
When thou ringeth the Bell of Awakening,
the fate of the Undead thou shalt know..."
The fate of the undead.
With nothing else to go on, the undead knights of Berenike ventured to Lordran
which was told to be at the heart of the undead curse.
They were right.
The Gods were partly responsible for the crumbling world.
The light in Anor Londo is an illusion and many gods have already abandoned
the world of men.
For the real light, the First Flame,
was fading.
There was one path into Anor Londo and that was through Sen's fortress.
So the knights of Berenike threw themselves at the deadly castle trying
to force their way through.
And they were not the only ones.
Within Sen's fortress we see the hollowed forms of both knights of Berenike
and Balder.
Two nations that attempted to reach the land of the gods. Desperate to discover
the fate of the undead.
Near the top of Sen's fortress there's an undead man who desperately tries to
retain his sanity.
Remember... counts... count, yeah... count! Counts
counts number one... one, two, three, fff...
four, four four fff..
ffive, five fivesix, seven! Count! Arghh.. Hrmmm!!
I can't... Hrrgggggggg!!
He has seen all the heroes pass through Sen's fortress never to return.
"For a century, they have tried,
and failed. The Knight King Rendal, Black Iron Tarkus, and even Logan himself.
You won't stand a chance. You'll be eaten alive. But,
go along, if you wish.
If only to deepen your despair !"
They all failed.
Every knight of Berenike, every Balder knight,
the Knight King Rendal and Logan himself.
Every one of them failed...
Except Tarkus.
Tarkus conquers the fortress, leaving his hollowed brothers behind.
He carves his summoning sign at the top of Sen's fortress so his spirit will be
able to aid anyone else who comes as far as he does.
Time is convoluted in Lordran and even if Tarkus is already dead, his spirit will
remain to aid those who need help with the final step
even if those heroes exist in another dimension.
For guarding the final steps to Anor Londo is the Iron Golem.
It is said that the soul of this construct was originally the bone of an
Everlasting Dragon
and it has slain countless heroes seeking Anor Londo.
For the sake of all those who came before him Tarkus prevails.
He becomes the first one to make it to Anor Londo.
But the tragedy begins here.
For when Tarkus arrive in Anor Londo he finds the path retracted before
him
He must break into the palace by the only path available :
up a narrow ledge, through the window and across the ceiling rafters protected by
Painting Guardians.
This operation runs counter to his skills,
encumbered by his armor and huge weaponry Tarkus falls to his death on the rafters
and is dragged into a corner by the Painting Guardians.
But his death was not in vain because now the path is clear and Tarkus
helped you there.
For the sake of the fallen we carry on.

title: Dark Souls Story ► Black Iron Tarkus
